steps.title: Compute parametric derivatives
steps.content: dx/dt = 3t^2/(t^3+1) and dy/dt = π cos(πt).

steps.title: Evaluate at t = 1 and form dy/dx
steps.content: At t=1, dx/dt = 3/2 and dy/dt = -π. Therefore dy/dx = (-π)/(3/2) = -(2/3)π, matching option ②.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: Confirmed the reasoning from all attempts; no corrections required.

steps.title: Set up the parametric derivative formula
steps.content:
For parametric equations x = f(t) and y = g(t), the derivative dy/dx is given by:
dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt)

steps.title: Calculate dx/dt
steps.content:
Given x = ln(t³ + 1)
Using the chain rule:
dx/dt = 1/(t³ + 1) · 3t² = 3t²/(t³ + 1)

At t = 1:
dx/dt = 3(1)²/(1³ + 1) = 3/2

steps.title: Calculate dy/dt
steps.content:
Given y = sin(πt)
Using the chain rule:
dy/dt = cos(πt) · π = π·cos(πt)

At t = 1:
dy/dt = π·cos(π) = π·(-1) = -π

steps.title: Calculate dy/dx at t = 1
steps.content:
dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt)
dy/dx = (-π)/(3/2)
dy/dx = -π · (2/3)
dy/dx = -2π/3 = -⅔π

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: All three attempts arrived at the same answer using identical correct methodology. The parametric derivative formula was applied correctly, both dx/dt and dy/dt were calculated accurately using the chain rule, and the final computation at t=1 gives dy/dx = -2π/3, which corresponds to choice ②.

steps.title: Compute parametric derivatives
steps.content: For x = ln(t^3 + 1), dx/dt = [3t^2 / (t^3 + 1)]. For y = sin(πt), dy/dt = π cos(πt). Thus, dy/dx = [π cos(πt)] / [3t^2 / (t^3 + 1)] = [π cos(πt) (t^3 + 1)] / (3t^2).

Grok 4 Fast.feedback: All attempts incorrectly used x = ln(t^2 + 1) instead of ln(t^3 + 1), leading to wrong dx/dt. Corrected by using proper derivative 3t^2/(t^3+1), resulting in -2π/3.

steps.title: Differentiate x(t) and y(t)
steps.content: dx/dt = 3t^2/(t^3+1), dy/dt = π cos(πt).

steps.title: Form dy/dx
steps.content: dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt) = π cos(πt) · (t^3+1)/(3t^2).

GPT-5.feedback: All three attempts used the correct parametric differentiation and evaluation at t=1; no corrections were necessary.

steps.title: Differentiate x with respect to t
steps.content:
Given $x = \ln(t^3 + 1)$, apply the chain rule. Let $u = t^3 + 1$, then $\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{u} \cdot \frac{du}{dt}$. Since $\frac{du}{dt} = 3t^2$, we have:
$$ \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{3t^2}{t^3 + 1} $$

steps.title: Differentiate y with respect to t
steps.content:
Given $y = \sin(\pi t)$, apply the chain rule:
$$ \frac{dy}{dt} = \cos(\pi t) \cdot \frac{d}{dt}(\pi t) = \pi \cos(\pi t) $$

steps.title: Evaluate derivatives at t = 1
steps.content:
Substitute $t=1$ into the derivative expressions:
$$ \left. \frac{dx}{dt} \right|_{t=1} = \frac{3(1)^2}{1^3 + 1} =  rac{3}{2} $$
$$ \left. \frac{dy}{dt} \right|_{t=1} = \pi \cos(\pi) = \pi(-1) = -\pi $$

steps.title: Calculate dy/dx
steps.content:
Using the parametric differentiation formula $\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy/dt}{dx/dt}$:
$$ \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-\pi}{3/2} = -\pi \cdot \frac{2}{3} = -\frac{2}{3}\pi $$

Gemini 3 Pro.feedback: All three previous attempts correctly applied the chain rule and the parametric derivative formula. The calculations were accurate across all instances.

steps.title: Set up the parametric derivative formula
steps.content:
For a curve defined parametrically by x = f(t) and y = g(t), the derivative dy/dx is computed using:
dy/dx = (dy/dt) / (dx/dt)

steps.title: Compute dx/dt
steps.content:
Given x = ln(t³ + 1), I apply the chain rule.
Let u = t³ + 1, so x = ln(u).
dx/du = 1/u and du/dt = 3t²
Therefore: dx/dt = (1/(t³ + 1)) · 3t² = 3t²/(t³ + 1)

steps.title: Compute dy/dt
steps.content:
Given y = sin(πt), I apply the chain rule.
dy/dt = cos(πt) · π = π cos(πt)

steps.title: Evaluate dy/dt at t = 1
steps.content: dy/dt|_{t=1} = π cos(π · 1) = π cos(π) = π · (-1) = -π

self_aggregation.rationale: All five model solutions arrive at the same answer through consistent calculations. The derivatives dx/dt = 3t²/(t³+1) and dy/dt = π cos(πt) are correctly computed, and evaluating at t=1 gives dx/dt = 3/2 and dy/dt = -π, resulting in dy/dx = -2π/3.

steps.title: Compute parametric derivatives
steps.content: For x = ln(t^3 + 1) and y = sin(πt), compute dx/dt = 3t^2/(t^3 + 1) and dy/dt = π cos(πt).

steps.title: Evaluate at t = 1
steps.content: At t = 1, dx/dt = 3/2 and dy/dt = -π, so dy/dx = (-π)/(3/2) = -(2/3)π.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: Approach matches Claude, GPT-5, and Gemini, all yielding -(2/3)π. Grok’s solution made a typo (ln(t^2 + 1)). No changes needed.

steps.title: Set up the parametric derivative formula
steps.content:
For parametric equations x = f(t) and y = g(t), the derivative dy/dx is given by:
dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt)

steps.title: Calculate dx/dt
steps.content:
Given x = ln(t³ + 1)
Using the chain rule:
dx/dt = 1/(t³ + 1) · 3t² = 3t²/(t³ + 1)

At t = 1:
dx/dt = 3(1)²/(1³ + 1) = 3/2

steps.title: Calculate dy/dt
steps.content:
Given y = sin(πt)
Using the chain rule:
dy/dt = cos(πt) · π = π·cos(πt)

At t = 1:
dy/dt = π·cos(π) = π·(-1) = -π

steps.title: Calculate dy/dx at t = 1
steps.content:
dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt) = (-π)/(3/2) = -π · (2/3) = -2π/3

This corresponds to option ②: -2π/3

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: My solution matches GPT-5-Codex, GPT-5, and Gemini 3 Pro. All of us correctly computed dx/dt = 3t²/(t³+1) = 3/2 at t=1, dy/dt = π·cos(π) = -π at t=1, and dy/dx = -π/(3/2) = -2π/3. Grok 4 Fast made an error by using t² + 1 instead of t³ + 1 in the x equation, leading to an incorrect answer of -π. My original solution was correct, no changes needed.

steps.title: Compute derivatives with respect to t
steps.content: For x = ln(t^3 + 1), dx/dt = 3t^2 / (t^3 + 1). For y = sin(πt), dy/dt = π cos(πt).

Grok 4 Fast.feedback: My original solution incorrectly used x = ln(t^2 + 1) instead of ln(t^3 + 1), leading to wrong dx/dt. All other models correctly used t^3, yielding dy/dx = -(2/3)π. I corrected this error to match.

steps.title: Differentiate parametric equations
steps.content: dx/dt = 3t^2/(t^3+1), dy/dt = π cos(πt).

steps.title: Form dy/dx
steps.content: dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt) = π cos(πt) · (t^3+1)/(3t^2).

GPT-5.feedback: My solution matches GPT-5-Codex, Claude, and Gemini, all yielding -2π/3 (option ②). Grok 4 Fast misread x as ln(t^2+1), leading to -π. No changes needed.

steps.title: Compute dx/dt
steps.content:
To find dy/dx, we first differentiate x with respect to t. Given x = ln(t^3 + 1), we apply the chain rule:
dx/dt = 1/(t^3 + 1) * d/dt(t^3 + 1) = (3t^2)/(t^3 + 1)

steps.title: Compute dy/dt
steps.content:
Next, we differentiate y with respect to t. Given y = sin(pi t), applying the chain rule gives:
dy/dt = cos(pi t) * d/dt(pi t) = pi cos(pi t)

steps.title: Evaluate derivative at t=1
steps.content:
Using the parametric differentiation formula dy/dx = (dy/dt) / (dx/dt), we substitute t=1 into the derivatives we found.

First, evaluate dx/dt at t=1:
dx/dt = (3(1)^2)/(1^3 + 1) = 3/2

Next, evaluate dy/dt at t=1:
dy/dt = pi cos(pi * 1) = pi(-1) = -pi

Finally, calculate dy/dx:
dy/dx = (-pi) / (3/2) = -pi * (2/3) = -(2/3)pi

Gemini 3 Pro.feedback: My solution aligns with GPT-5-Codex, Claude Opus 4.5, and GPT-5, all of which correctly identified the function x = ln(t^3 + 1). Grok 4 Fast incorrectly transcribed the function as ln(t^2 + 1), leading to a wrong derivative and final answer. My calculation remains correct.

steps.title: Understand the parametric derivative formula
steps.content: For a curve defined parametrically as x = x(t) and y = y(t), the derivative dy/dx can be computed using the chain rule: dy/dx = (dy/dt) / (dx/dt), provided dx/dt ≠ 0.

steps.title: Compute dx/dt
steps.content:
Given x = ln(t³ + 1), I apply the chain rule. The derivative of ln(u) is 1/u times du/dt.
So dx/dt = (1/(t³ + 1)) · d/dt(t³ + 1) = (1/(t³ + 1)) · 3t² = 3t²/(t³ + 1)

steps.title: Compute dy/dt
steps.content:
Given y = sin(πt), I apply the chain rule. The derivative of sin(u) is cos(u) times du/dt.
So dy/dt = cos(πt) · d/dt(πt) = cos(πt) · π = π cos(πt)

steps.title: Evaluate dx/dt at t = 1
steps.content:
Substituting t = 1 into dx/dt = 3t²/(t³ + 1):
dx/dt|_{t=1} = 3(1)²/(1³ + 1) = 3/2

steps.title: Evaluate dy/dt at t = 1
steps.content:
Substituting t = 1 into dy/dt = π cos(πt):
dy/dt|_{t=1} = π cos(π·1) = π cos(π) = π · (-1) = -π

steps.title: Calculate dy/dx at t = 1
steps.content:
Using the formula dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt):
dy/dx|_{t=1} = (-π)/(3/2) = -π · (2/3) = -2π/3

cross_aggregation.rationale: All model solutions arrived at the same answer using the correct parametric differentiation formula. Each step in their solutions is mathematically sound: the chain rule applications for both dx/dt and dy/dt are correct, and the evaluation at t=1 yields dx/dt = 3/2 and dy/dt = -π, giving dy/dx = -2π/3.
